Graphical abstract V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 monolithic catalysts were evaluated for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 in the presence of SO2 and H2O. After a durability test at 220 °C for 30 h, the NO x conversion of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 increased from 70% to 88% while it decreased slightly over V2O5-WO3/TiO2. The catalysts were characterized by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3, thermo-gravimetric (TG) analysis, temperature-programmed decomposition (TPD) of deposits, temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of ammonium bisulfates with NO, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) and diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy. There were fewer sulfates deposits on VMoTi-S catalyst due to lower SO2 oxidation which was related to less VOV bonds on the Mo-modified catalyst. The as-formed high proportioned stable tridentate sulfates on VMoTi-S catalyst acted as strong Brønsted acid sites, and more active polymeric vanadates remained on this catalyst to activate the absorbed NH4 +. The separation of acid sites and active sites which facilitates NH2 formation was suggested to be responsible for the promoted SCR activity of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 during NH3-SCR reaction. Keywords NH3-SCR Molybdenum Vanadate Ammonium bisulfate Amidogen 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emitted from stationary and mobile sources are important pollutants which result in photochemical smog, acid rain, ozone depletion and greenhouse effects [1]. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO with NH3 has been proven to be a mature technology of controlling NO x emissions in terms of removal efficiency, stability and economics [2,3]. V2O5 supported on anatase TiO2, which is promoted by WO3 or MoO3, is currently being commercialized for stationary applications owing to its stability and high catalytic activity at 200–450 °C [4,5]. When the temperature of diesel exhaust gases such as those from large marine diesel engine is generally lower than 300 °C [6,7], the high concentrations of SO2 in flue gas may result in serious deactivation and shorten the catalyst lifespan. Researches show that the sulfated active component and the coverage effect of as-formed NH4HSO4 are the main causes of catalyst deactivation when temperature is below 300 °C [8,9]. Oxidation of SO2 to SO3 can be promoted by catalysts, and the as-formed SO3 can interact with H2O and NH3 in gas to form NH4HSO4, covering the active sites on catalyst surface [10]. Therefore, one of the primary goals for industrialization is to develop low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts with high sulfur resistance or catalysts which can be promoted by sulfur oxides. On the other hand, significant efforts have also been devoted to figuring out the beneficial effects of SO2 on the SCR activities of some specific catalysts in the past decades [11–14]. Huang et al. [11] and Baraket et al. [12] found the positive effect of SO2 on the SCR activities of V2O5/AC (activated carbon) and V2O5/TiO2 is due to the promoted acidity from as-formed surface sulfates and improved redox properties of vanadates on the catalyst surface. However, L. Baraket simply ascribed the promoting effect of sulfur on the redox property to strong electronic interaction between vanadia and sulfates. Li et al. [13] and Wu et al. [14] observed similar positive effect of SO2 on the SCR activity of CeO2 catalyst with increased acidity. However, it should be noted that these catalysts themselves lacked enough acid sites which played an important role in NH3-SCR reaction and hereby could be compensated by the formed sulfates on the catalyst surface. Molybdenum (Mo) has been proven to be a beneficial additive in V2O5/TiO2 based catalysts for its good sulfur resistance [15,16]. However, the corresponding modification mechanism has rarely been explored until Kwon et al. [16] who found the enhancement of Mo lies in its effects on reducing SO2 adsorption and SO2 oxidation. Nevertheless, the powder catalyst exhibited a continuous decrease in the presence of 500 ppm SO2 at 250 °C for 60 h. Moreover, it failed to figure out the transformation of active sites and how sulfates act as acid sites after sulfation. This study aimed to figuring out the mechanism of SO2’s promotion effect on the NH3-SCR activity of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst from viewpoint of the separation of acid sites and active sites which facilitates NH2 formation. In this way, this study offered insight into designing low-temperature SCR catalysts with high durability in the presence of sulfur. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The VWTi and VMoTi monolithic catalysts were prepared by an extrusion molding method. The precursor of VMoTi was prepared by impregnating TiO2 powers (cp, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, China) in an aqueous solution of ammonium heptamolybdate (cp, Sinopharm) and ammonium metavanadate (cp, Sinopharm) with a mass ratio of V2O5:Mo2O3:TiO2 = 1:4:95. After stirring for 3 h, the solution was titrated with 20 wt.% ammonia hydroxide (cp, Sinopharm) until the pH exceeded 8. After filtration, the resulting precipitates were dried in air for 24 h. The catalyst was calcined at 620 °C for 3 h in air after extrusion molding. The appearance of the monolithic catalyst was shown in Fig. S1 and its size was 35 mm × 35 mm × 200 mm. For comparison, the VWTi (with a mass ratio of V2O5:WO3:TiO2 = 1:4:95) catalyst was prepared by the same method with ammonium paratungstate as one of the precursors. The sulfated catalysts after the SCR reaction in the presence of SO2 for 30 h were denoted to VMoTi-S and VWTi-S, respectively. Incipient impregnation was used to prepare the ABS (NH4HSO4) or AS ((NH4)2SO4) impregnated samples with a loading amount of 1 wt.% [17,18]. The monolithic catalysts were crushed into powder. The aqueous solution of ABS/AS was added dropwise to the powder catalyst. The mixture was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and the obtained samples were denoted with a suffix of "−1%ABS" or "−1%ABS". 2.2 SCR activity measurement NH3-SCR activity measurement was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tube at 250 °C. The feed stream consisted of 1000 ppm NH3, 1000 ppm NO, 5% O2, 300 ppm SO2, 10% H2O and N2 in balance with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 5000 h−1. The outlet gas was monitored by a flue gas analyzer (ecom EN-2 F, RBR, Germany). The durability test was performed at 250 °C for 30 h. The NO x conversion was calculated according to the equation below. (1) N O x conversion % = NO i n − NO o u t − N O 2 o u t NO i n × 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 (USA). To minimize the influence of sulfates, the sulfated catalysts were pre-reduced in a 10% H2/Ar flow (50 ml/min) by running TPR from room temperature (RT) to 600 °C and then re-oxidized in 20% O2 (air, 50 ml/min) at 600 °C for 30 min. For comparison, the fresh catalysts experienced the same redox process. After such a desulfation treatment, no H2S or SO2 signal was detected by Mass Spectrum (MS) when performing the successive H2-TPR test, indicating the complete removal of decomposable/reducible sulfates. Although vanadium species do not remain at the original state after the pretreatment, the redox property of catalysts was suggested not to change significantly [19]. After the catalyst pretreatment, the reactor was then heated in a 10% H2/Ar flow (50 ml/min) from RT to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and the data were recorded. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor with the effluent gases monitored using a Thermo Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer (USA). Prior to the experiment, 250 mg sample was pretreated in a gas flow of 5% O2/N2 at 200 °C for 60 min. Then the sample was cooled down to 100 °C and exposed to NH3 until saturation, followed by flushing with N2 to try to remove physisorbed NH3. Afterwards, the NH3-saturated sample was ramped in N2 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The thermo-gravimetric (TG) analysis was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC instrument (Swiss) from RT to 600 °C in N2 (50 ml/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The temperature-programmed decomposition (TPD) of deposits on the sulfated catalysts was carried out in N2 (50 ml/min) from RT to 600 °C at a heat rate of 10 °C min−1. The outlet gas was monitored by a mass spectrometer (Omnistar 200, Germany). The temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with NO was carried out over the catalysts impregnated with 1% ABS or 1% AS. The feed stream consisted of 1000 ppm NO, 5% O2 and N2 in balance with a GHSV of 120,000 h−1. The outlet gas was analyzed by a Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer. In situ diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra was recorded by an FT-IR 6700 (Thermo Nicolet, USA) equipped with an in situ diffuse reflection chamber and MCT detector. Prior to the experiment, the catalyst was heated in a flow of 5% O2/N2 at 200 °C for 60 min and then cooled to 100 °C. The spectra of catalyst in a flow of 500 ppm NH3/N2 were collected at a resolution of 4 cm−1 with the accumulation of 16 scans. SO2 oxidation was carried out under a steady-state condition at 250 °C. The inlet gas consisted of 300 ppm SO2, 5% O2 and N2 in balance at total flow rate of 500 ml/min. The concentration of the outlet SO2 was determined by a NDIR ECOM EN2 (Horiba, Japan) analyzer. After running for 5 h, the outlet SO2 concentration kept stable (<±2 ppm). The conversion of SO2 to SO3 was calculated by the equation below: (2) S O 2 oxidation % = S O 2 i n − S O 2 o u t S O 2 i n × 100 The surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) was conducted with an optical fiber micro-Raman system (i-Raman Plus, B&W TEK Inc.). Raman spectra were obtained using a 785 nm laser as the excitation source with its beam spot focused to ∼80 μm in diameter and an excitation power of 75 mW. The data collection time for each spectrum was 10 s, and the wavenumber values were accurate to 4 cm−1. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) absorption spectroscopy was measured by using an UV–vis spectrophotometer (Hitachi U-3010) equipped with an integrating sphere. A BaSO4 pellet was used as a reference. The spectra were recorded at RT in a wavelength range 200–800 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SCR activity and sulfur tolerance To evaluate the durability of the monolithic catalysts, a SO2 resistance test was performed in the presence of 300 ppm SO2 and 10% H2O at 250 °C for 30 h and the results are shown Fig. 1 . VWTi initially experiences a degreening effect [20] and then keeps a slight decrease in activity for the rest time. In the end of the test, a small drop of 2% occurs for the NO x conversion over VWTi catalyst while VMoTi exhibits an evident increase of NO x conversion from 70% to 88%. Almost no NO2 or N2O was detected within the whole temperature range. To confirm the dependency of this activity increase on SO2, another durability test was performed in the absence of SO2 and the result is shown in Fig. S2. It is inferred that SO2 has a significant promoting effect on the NH3-SCR activity of VMoTi catalyst, while it deactivates VWTi catalyst to a small extent. 3.2 Vanadia species of catalysts H2-TPR test was performed to determine the redox property of the catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The reduction profiles were deconvoluted into three overlapped peaks, which are centered at 342, 415 and 471 °C for VWTi. The first peak is ascribed to the reduction of V5+→V3+ [21–23]. The second and third peaks correspond to the successive reduction of surface W6+→W4+ and bulk W6+→W4+, respectively [24–26]. As for VMoTi catalyst, the first peak assigned to the vanadium reduction shifts to 378 °C, while the second and third peaks corresponding to the successive reduction of surface Mo6+→Mo 5.4+ and bulk Mo6+→Mo 5.4+ are located at 420 and 470 °C, respectively [27]. The H2 consumption of the first peak, which represents the amount of reducible vanadia species quasi-quantitatively, are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the modification of molybdenum decreases the amount of active vanadium sites on VMoTi to some extent, accounting for the reduced activity of the fresh catalyst. Nevertheless, the active vanadium sites on VMoTi-S experience only a loss of 30% while those on VWTi-S decreases by about 80%, indicating that the Mo-modified catalyst has a stronger resistance to sulfur poisoning in terms of redox property. To further elucidate the transformation of surface active vanadium species after sulfation, the SERS and UV–vis tests were performed and the results are shown in Fig. 3 (a) and (b), respectively. For the surface-enhanced Raman spectra, bands at 1030, 1015 and 983 cm−1 can be detected on VWTi catalyst. The band at 1030 cm−1 is due to the VO stretching mode of dispersed vanadia species, which occurs predominantly as isolated monovanadate [28–31]. The band at 1015 cm−1 is ascribed to WO bond stretching mode. The band at 983 cm−1 is ascribed to the overlap of highly dispersed tungsten oxide and polymeric vanadate which is known to be more important for SCR reaction than monovanadate [32]. After the durability test, the band at 1030 cm−1 increases in intensity while that at 983 cm−1 almost vanishes for VWTi-S, indicating the transformation of monovanadates to polymeric vanadates and the disappearance of highly dispersed tungsten species on catalyst surface. This evident decrease of active vanadium sites corroborates the H2-TPR results in Fig. 2 and implies that sulfur species combine strongly with dispersed vanadia species on VWTi catalyst upon the durability test. Similar bands at 1024 and 983 cm−1 are also detected on VMoTi and VMoTi-S catalysts. The band at 1024 cm−1 is due to the VO stretching mode of monomeric vanadia species. The band at 983 cm−1 may be ascribed to the overlap of terminal MoO stretching [33] and polymeric vanadate. Since VO species is much more sensitive to Raman signal than MoO species over titania surface [34], the latter one was likely to be overshadowed by the strong Raman band of vanadium species. Therefore, the band in this range arises mainly from the structure transformation of vanadium species. Compared with the VWTi catalyst, the vanadium species on the Mo modified catalyst presents a reverse transformation after the durability test, indicating more active polymeric vanadate formed on VMoTi-S. To confirm these results, UV–vis test was performed and the spectra are shown in Fig. 3(b). The spectra are dominated by the edge relative to the O2−→Ti4+ charge transfer of the anatase support at 380 nm [35]. A broad absorption edge in the range 450–550 nm is sensitive to the coordination structure of vanadia, and the higher the absorption edge wavelength, the higher the coordination of polymeric vanadia species [36]. In this case, the absorption edge position increases from 447 to 478 nm for the Mo modified catalyst after sulfation, suggesting the redispersion of vanadia and an increase of their polymerization degree. In comparison, the absorption edge position also increases slightly from 465 nm to 479 nm. This increase is mainly due to SO4 2− rather than vanadia species since there are more sulfates deposited on VWTi-S catalyst surface and sulfates can evidently elevate the absorption edge position according to literatures [37] as well as our experiment results (Fig. S3). 3.3 Sulfate deposits on catalyst surface 3.3.1 Identification of surface deposits To investigate the mechanism of SO2 modification on the activity of VMoTi, several experiments were performed to characterize possible structural changes after the durability test. No obvious differences are observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. S4) and BET (Table 1) data of the fresh and sulfated catalysts. Only the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 are observed, and those of vanadium oxide, tungsten oxide or molybdenum oxide do not appear due to their low contents or low crystallinity. Crystallite sulfates detectable by XRD are not found on the sulfated catalysts, either. The BET surface areas of the sulfated catalysts would generally decrease due to the pore blocking effect of the deposited sulfates. Contrarily, they increase to some extent in this case, which may be caused by extra contribution of surface SO4 2− species [38], as shown in Fig. S5. Anyway, significant influences of these structural properties on the catalytic activity can be excluded. It has been reported that the NH4HSO4 deposition on catalyst surface and the chemical poisoning of active sites are two main factors that account for the catalyst deactivation with SO2-containing exhaust at low temperatures [39,40]. To identify the surface sulfate species and estimate their deposition amounts, TG and TPD analyses were performed. Fig. 4 shows the TG profiles of the catalysts and Table S1 lists the mass loss data at different stages. For the fresh catalysts, the major mass loss occurs in Stage 1 (RT-250 °C), attributed to the release of physically adsorbed H2O on the catalysts [41]. For the sulfated catalysts, another major mass loss occurs in Stage 2 (250–450 °C), which is believed to arise from the decomposition of NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4 [42–45]. The small drop in Stage 3 (450–600 °C) is attributed to decomposition of metal (V, Ti and W/Mo) sulfates on the sulfated catalysts [46–48]. Remarkably, the mass losses in Stage 2 and 3 on VMoTi-S (0.29% and 0.07%) are much smaller than those on VWTi-S (0.95% and 0.32%) as listed in Table 2 , indicating that much less NH4HSO4 and metal sulfates have been deposited on VMoTi-S during the durability test. To further identify the species of surface deposits, TPD tests of the sulfated, NH4HSO4 (ABS)-impregnated and (NH4)2SO4 (AS)-impregnated catalysts were performed in N2 and the results are shown in Fig. 5 and Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 5a, the NH3 desorption peak temperature of VWTi-S (377 °C) is closer to that of the VWTi impregnated with 1% ABS (360 °C) rather than that with AS (302 °C). A similar phenomenon is found over VMoTi-S. It is therefore reasonable to ascribe the main sulfate species on the sulfated catalysts to ABS rather than AS, corresponding to the mass loss in Stage 2 at 300–450 °C in Fig. 4. Remarkably, the ratio of NH3/SO2 desorption over VMoTi-S is 1.9, which is much higher than that over VWTi-S (0.8) and is close to the data over the AS-impregnated catalysts. The excessive NH3 on VMoTi-S may be due to NH3 chemisorbed on more medium strong/strong surface acid sites during the continuous SCR reaction, which will be later confirmed by the ammonia desorption results in Section 3.4.1. On the other hand, the ratio of NH3/SO2 desorption over VWTi-S is only 0.8, even slightly lower than that of the ABS-impregnated catalysts. Excessive SO2 release may be ascribed to the desorption of more chemically adsorbed SO x during the durability test, which correlates well with the report [16] that VWTi has a stronger adsorption ability of SO2 than VMoTi catalyst as well as our SO2-TPD results in Fig. S6. To further identify the metal sulfates formed during sulfation, the fresh catalysts were exposed to SO2 + O2 for different time and the obtained in situ DRIFT spectra were presented in Fig. 6 . Several bands at 1407, 1376, 1332, 1318, and 1270 cm−1 are detected on VWTi catalyst in Fig. 6(a), and their intensities increase with time. The band at 1407 cm−1 could be assigned to SO3 species [49]. The bands at 1332 cm−1 and 1318 cm−1 are ascribed to gaseous SO2 [10] and antisymmetric SO vibration of the weakly bound form of surface SO2 [50], respectively. Notably, the band at 1376 cm−1 is assigned to the terminal SO bond of tridentate surface sulfate [51,52] while the strongest band at 1270 cm−1 is assigned to bidentate sulfates [49,53]. Similar bands at 1403, 1363, 1334, 1320, and 1270 cm−1 are also observed on VMoTi catalyst in Fig. 6(b). Interestingly, the band at 1363 cm−1 assigned to tridentate surface sulfates is relatively strong on VMoTi compared with VWTi. This result implies that more tridentate surface sulfates are formed on the Mo-modified catalyst surface in addition to bidentate sulfates. The importance of these tridentate sulfates for NH3-SCR will be discussed later in Section 3.4.1. 3.3.2 Factors influencing sulfate deposition As mentioned above, the deposition of sulfates on catalyst surface depends not only on the SO2 oxidation activity and the adsorption of SO3, but also on the reactivity of the deposited sulfates with NO. The former factors decide the formation of sulfates while the latter determines possible consumption of the deposited sulfates. It can be seen in Fig. S6 that the SO2 adsorption ability of VWTi catalyst is almost twice that of VMoTi catalyst while the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 over VWTi and VMoTi at 250 °C is 1.7% and 0.1%, respectively (Table 1). This result indicates that good SO2 adsorption ability does not equal good SO2 oxidation ability. And it is the SO2 oxidation ability of a catalyst that determines its sulfur resistance [54]. The SO2 oxidation ability difference of W-modified and Mo-modified catalysts may be due to there are more polymeric vanadates on VWTi catalyst, indicating the formation of more VOV species on the W-modified catalyst surface. Meanwhile, the vanadium species on VMoTi catalyst are mainly in the form of monovanadates which own few VOV bonds and are not as active as polymeric vanadates. Previous research [10] claims that the oxidation reaction from SO2 to SO3 on vanadium oxides mainly occurs on the VOV bonds rather on VO bonds, accounting for the reduced activity of VMoTi for SO2 oxidation. Although the deposited sulfates on VMoTi-S surface are more stable in N2 than on VWTi-S catalyst as shown in Figs. 5 and 6, the NH4 + ions in deposited NH4HSO4 on the former catalyst have higher reactivity with NO, which can accelerate the consumption of the deposited NH4HSO4 and further reduce the final deposition of sulfates after the durability test. In addition to the total amount of sulfate deposition, different types of sulfates and their relative percentages were estimated by TG and MS. As listed in Table S1, there are at least two major sulfates formed on the catalysts, i.e. ammonium hydrogen sulfate and metal sulfates, and the former one is the dominant sulfate deposited during the low-temperature SCR reaction. There are excess NH3 and SO2/SO3 chemically adsorbed in VMoTi-S and VWTi-S, respectively. 3.4 NH3 adsorption and NH2 formation 3.4.1 NH3 adsorption of catalysts A NH3-TPD test was performed to measure the amounts and strengths of acid sites on catalyst surface. The desorption curves are shown in Fig. 7 and the amounts of total NH3 desorption estimated by integrating the peak areas are listed in Table 4 . All the catalysts show a bimodal shape with one peak at about 250 °C (ascribed to weak acid sites) and the other at about 370 °C (ascribed to medium strong acid sites). The first peak at about 160 °C is generally ascribed to weakly adsorbed NH3 and therefore was excluded when discussing surface acidity [55,56]. The last peak is ascribed to strong acid sites and was counted together with the medium strong acid sites in Table 4. After sulfation, the total amount of desorbed NH3 increases for VMoTi-S and especially VWTi-S. The increased surface acidity of the sulfated catalysts is closely related to the formation of surface sulfates including ammonium bisulfate and metal sulfates. Notably, an evident increase in the amount of medium strong and strong acid sites occurs for VMoTi-S while it only shows a little increase for VWTi-S. Interestingly, the amount of weak acid sites decreases slightly for VMoTi-S while that for VWTi-S increases significantly. This may be ascribed to a fact that the sulfate species on VMoTi-S surface is more stable and can act as medium strong/strong acid sites while that on VWTi-S surface fails to have the same effect. It should be noted that the decomposition of ammonium bisulfate also contributes to the total NH3 desorption of the sulfated catalysts. According to TG (Fig. 4) and TPD results (Fig. 5), there are much less ABS on VMoTi-S catalyst surface and thus the NH3 from ABS decomposition should contribute less to the total NH3 desorption on this catalyst in the NH3-TPD test. It can herein be concluded that VMoTi-S possesses more medium strong/strong acid sites than VWTi-S. To figure out the influence of such strong acid sites enhancement on the activation of ammonia on VMoTi-S, a DRIFT study of NH3 desorption was performed and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The catalysts were pre-exposed to a flow of NH3 for 60 min followed by N2 purging for 30 min at 100 °C. Several bands at 1665, 1602, 1550, and 1503 cm−1 are observed at 100 °C on VWTi catalyst in Fig. 8(a). The band at 1602 cm−1 is assigned to asymmetric bending vibrations of the NH bonds in coordinated NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites [33,57]. The bands at 1665 and 1503 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites [58,59]. The band at 1550 cm−1 is assigned to bending vibrations of the HNH bonds in NH2 species [60,61]. With the temperature elevated from 100 to 500 °C, the Brønsted acid bands decrease in intensity more quickly than the Lewis acid ones. As the temperature is above 400 °C, only weak bands of Lewis acid sites can be observed. It indicates that Lewis acid sites are stronger than Brønsted acid sites on VWTi catalyst, corresponding to the NH3 desorption above 400 °C in Fig. 7. Similar DRIFT spectra are observed for VMoTi catalyst in Fig. 8(b). Compared with VWTi catalyst, VMoTi remains a larger number of strong acid sites at high temperatures, which is also in accordance with the NH3-TPD results. After sulfation, it is evident in Fig. 8(c) that the band at 1665 cm−1 ascribed to ammonia adsorbed at Brønsted acid sites shifts noticeably to higher wavenumbers (1680 cm−1) and increases in intensity on VWTi-S, while the band at 1602 cm−1 ascribed to ammonia adsorbed at Lewis acid sites decreases evidently in intensity. It indicates that the durability test increases the strength and amount of Brønsted acid sites which arise from newly formed acid sites by SO4 2−, but decreases the amount of Lewis acid sites from vanadium oxide, which is on account of the vanadyl sites coverage by NH4HSO4 and metal sulfates [13]. A similar shift of the band assigned to Brønsted acid sites from 1650 to 1683 cm−1 occurs in the spectra of VMoTi-S in Fig. 8(d). Nevertheless, the decrease in intensity of the Lewis acid sites related band (1602 cm−1) provided mainly by vanadium species are not so obvious, which is ascribed to the deposition of much less sulfates on this catalyst. Furthermore, the Brønsted acid sites related band (1503 cm−1) increases evidently in intensity in case of less deposited sulfates. This result is in accordance with Fig. 7 that the high proportioned more stable sulfates on VMoTi-S surface can act as strong acid sites. Interestingly, the band ascribed to NH2 at 1550 cm−1 becomes significantly sharper on the sulfated Mo-modified catalyst, which is of great benefit to SCR reaction. The significance of NH2 species during NH3-SCR reaction will be demonstrated in detail in Section 3.4.2. 3.4.2 Mechanism of NH2 formation on VMoTi-S catalyst According to Ramis [62] and Topsøe’s [63] researches, the active sites for NH3-SCR reaction of V-based catalyst are OVOVOH species mono-dispersed on TiO2 surface. Gaseous NH3 is mainly adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (in the form of V5+ OH) and afterwards the V5+ O species will activate the adsorbed NH3 (in the form of V5+ ONH4 +) into NH2. Such NH2 species can react with gaseous NO to form NH2NO which finally resolves into N2 and H2O. Therefore, NH2 species is a quite crucial activated product facilitating the NH3-SCR reaction, and the generation of abundant NH2 is in good accordance of increased activity of VMoTi-S. In this case, the co-existence of molybdenum oxide and deposited SO4 2− appears to activate NH2 more readily. Fig. 6 shows that more tridentate sulfates have formed on VMoTi-S catalyst surface while the metal sulfates on VWTi-S catalyst are mainly in the form of bidentate sulfates. According to Gao’s research [18], tridentate sulfates in the form of (MO)3SO is more stable than bidentate sulfates in the form of (M2SO4)H. Furthermore, the thermal decomposition results also demonstrate that the NH4HSO4 on VMoTi-S catalyst is also more stable than that on VWTi-S. Therefore, according to NH3-DRIFT results in Fig. 8(d), the as-formed more stable sulfates on VMoTi-S surface account for the greatly increased band intensity at 1503 cm−1 associated with Brønsted acid sites. Consequently, the more stable sulfates on VMoTi-S surface can be inferred to act as strong acid sites for NH3 adsorption and more NH3 can be adsorbed on such strong Brønsted acid sites provided by sulfates instead of V5+ OH sites, therefore releasing more active vanadium species on VMoTi-S catalyst. In support of this separation mechanism, the H2-TPR results in Fig. 2 and NH3-DRIFT results in Fig. 8 confirm the different state of active vanadium species on different catalysts. A large portion of active vanadium species on VWTi-S catalyst were eliminated by sulfur species or transformed into inactive monovanadates. In comparison, most of the active vanadium species on VMoTi-S catalyst remained after sulfation due to fewer sulfates deposits and even more active polymeric vanadates formed, indicating higher activation ability of NH4 + absorbed on stable sulfates on VMoTi-S catalyst. Since the stable sulfates on VMoTi-S surface act as strong Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption, the released active vanadium species in the form of VO can play its activation role as activating the adsorbed NH4 + instead of transforming into acid sites. Such separation of acid sites and active sites greatly facilitates the formation of active NH2 intermediate species on VMoTi-S catalyst surface, which can be confirmed by NH3-DRIFT results in Fig. 8(d). And the as-formed more NH2 can react with gaseous NO to form -NH2NO which finally resolves into N2 and H2O. This separation mechanism is illustrated in Scheme 1 . Notably, such separation mechanism only works for in-situ formed sulfates but not impregnated sulfates according to our results in Fig. S7 that no NH2 species can be observed on VMoTi catalyst impregnated with 1% NH4HSO4 under the same condition in Fig. 8. Additionally, the excess NH3 chemically absorbed on VMoTi-S catalyst surface (Fig.5) may also benefit the formation of NH2 by role of ammonia reservoir. 3.5 Reactivity of NH4HSO4 with NO The deposition of sulfates on catalyst surface depends not only on the SO2 oxidation activity and the adsorption of SO3, but also on the reaction of the deposited sulfates especially NH4HSO4 (ABS) with NO as a reducing agent [40,42]. Thus, the TPSR of ABS with NO over the catalysts was performed and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . No NO x conversion is observed on the fresh catalysts as shown in Fig. S8. Thus, variations in NO x conversion reflect different reactivity of NH4HSO4 on catalysts with NO. After impregnating NH4HSO4 on the fresh catalysts, two NO conversion peaks occur at about 175 and 325 °C, respectively. The first peak can be ascribed to the reaction between NH4 + in NH4HSO4 and gaseous NO while the second one is ascribed to the reaction of NH3 coming from the decomposition of NH4HSO4 and gaseous NO [18]. Given an ongoing reaction process, the NO x conversion begins to decrease and stops at ca. 380 °C. That could be explained by the deficiency of the ammonia species. The reaction between solid ABS and NO is more significantly catalyzed by VMoTi since the first peak is stronger on this catalyst, implying higher reactivity of NH4HSO4 with NO at temperatures below 250 °C. The second peak appears to be similar for the two catalysts. Fig. 9(b) shows the TPSR profiles of the NH4HSO4 impregnated on the sulfated catalysts. The NO x conversion data had been subtracted by those of the sulfated catalysts due to the deposition of ammonium hydrogen sulfate upon the durability test (Fig. S7). The NO x conversion peak at ca. 75 °C over the impregnated VMoTi-S is caused by the desorption of NO adsorbed on the sulfated catalyst at room temperature, which can be omitted in this case. The peak at ca. 175 °C, which is ascribed to the reaction between NH4 + in NH4HSO4 and gaseous NO, disappears on the impregnated VWTi-S, but remains to some extent on VMoTi-S-1%ABS. Meanwhile, the NO x conversion peak with NH3 coming from the decomposition of NH4HSO4 as the reducing agent occurs at ca. 300 °C on the impregnated VMoTi-S, which is greatly retarded on the impregnated VWTi-S (375 °C). It indicates that VMoTi-S can catalyze the reaction between solid ABS with NO better than VWTi-S. Therefore it can be inferred that the deposited NH4HSO4 on VMoTi-S would be consumed more quickly by reacting with NO as a reducing agent, which accounts partially for the SCR activity enhancement. This result is in good agreement with the NH3-DRIFT results that more NH2 species are observed on VMoTi-S, indicating the synergistic effect between the molybdenum modified catalyst and the formed sulfates. 4 Conclusions A comparison study on the sulfur tolerance of the MoO3 and WO3 modified V2O5/TiO2 catalysts was performed in this work. Some conclusions are drawn as follows. (1) The NO x conversion of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst increases evidently from 70% to 88% during a continuous NH3-SCR activity test at 250 °C for 30 h in the presence of sulfur dioxide and water, while a slight deactivation is observed for V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. (2) The lower redox property of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 is responsible for its reduced low-temperature activity compared with V2O5-WO3/TiO2. However, more active vanadium species remain on this catalyst after sulfation. (3) Much less sulfates are deposited on V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst during the durability test, due to its lower SO2 oxidation. The reaction of NH4HSO4 with NO is accelerated on this catalyst, which is another factor accounting for the less deposition of NH4HSO4. (4) High proportioned stable tridentate sulfates on VMoTi-S surface act as strong Brønsted acid sites. This liberates more active polymeric vanadates to activate the adsorbed NH4 + to form NH2 species as a crucial intermediate for NH3-SCR reaction. Nevertheless, if the concentration of SO2 is high enough or the runtime of NH3-SCR reaction is long enough, negative effects on the NO elimination are expected to occur finally due to the more SO3 production by SO2 oxidation and accumulation of ammonium bisulfate and metal sulfates on the surface of VMoTi catalysts. coredata.dc:description: V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 monolithic catalysts were evaluated for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 in the presence of SO2 and H2O. After a durability test at 220 °C for 30 h, the NO x conversion of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 increased from 70% to 88% while it decreased slightly over V2O5-WO3/TiO2. The catalysts were characterized by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of NH3, thermo-gravimetric (TG) analysis, temperature-programmed decomposition (TPD) of deposits, temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of ammonium bisulfates with NO, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) and diffuse reflection infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy. There were fewer sulfates deposits on VMoTi-S catalyst due to lower SO2 oxidation which was related to less VOV bonds on the Mo-modified catalyst. The as-formed high proportioned stable tridentate sulfates on VMoTi-S catalyst acted as strong Brønsted acid sites, and more active polymeric vanadates remained on this catalyst to activate the absorbed NH4 +. The separation of acid sites and active sites which facilitates NH2 formation was suggested to be responsible for the promoted SCR activity of V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 during NH3-SCR reaction.
coredata.dc:title: SO2 promoted V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO x at low temperatures
